Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation2: A homeowner reports a damaged wooden deck, and the carpenter needs to repair or replace it to restore functionality
Story: I stood at the edge of the driveway, toolbox in hand, my phone buzzing with a homeowner’s urgent message about their splintered deck. I glanced up to see my younger brother, helmet askew, eyeing the steep, cracked ramp with a wild grin. “Watch this!” he called, skateboard poised for a trick he’d only seen online. As his sibling, I knew I should stop him, make sure he didn’t break an arm—or worse. But the homeowner’s voice echoed in my mind, reminding me of the promise I’d made to fix their deck before the weekend barbecue. My reputation as a reliable carpenter was on the line, and I couldn’t afford to let them down. My heart pounded as I weighed the responsibility of keeping my brother safe against the professional duty pulling me toward my truck. I felt torn, rooted to the spot, unable to move in either direction, the demands of both roles pressing in on me, waiting for me to choose.
